answers.answer: My Primary Dr is good for routine things or when I have to wait weeks to get in to see the Endo, but my Endo is extremely thorough and leaves no stone unturned.  I firmly believe in a specialist for our special issues .. especially since they are so well trained and have taken years more of study in just this area.  Finding an Endo that isn't just diabetes is the project that makes it hard .. you need one well-versed in thyroid issues, too and willing to look outside of the textbook.

My (former) endo only checked TSH and occasionally FT4.  Never checked FT3. He just new it was high by process of elimination.  TSH undectectable + FT4 normal = FT3 must be high.  He claims to have specialized thyroid disorders in school and he has been practicing 10 years.  Pre-RAI, I asked,"Should I call you if I start feeling bad?"  He replied, "NO, you'll tough it out."  That was my LAST visit.My new MD has Hashi hypo.  He has been keeping a close eye on my labs so I don't crash.  He called in a standing order to the lab.  I can get blood work any time I'm feeling off.  He calls me with my results.  I told him that he's a keeper!

I voted for the ENT because he's the one who actually saw that my pcp was NOT treating ALL my problems.  The ENT is the one who ordered the blood work & U/S to dx the Hashi's/nodular goiter, etc.  He's also the one who referred me to the endo because he knew my pcp wasn't doing what I needed him to be doing.Now, I've seen my endo twice and although I'm not totally impressed with him, he DOES listen and he let me try cytomel, which made a world of difference in the way I feel when my pcp refused to even consider anything but synthroid.  I'm getting the blood work done that I need, etc so for now I'll stay with him.The ENT is still my favorite though.

My Endo is strictly a synthroid man.  I am leaning to Armour and my family doctor has said he would put me on that.  I just reached my level after 7 months but my endo does not care that I am still tired, have hair loss, and have gained 30 pounds.  The endo also informed me I am pre diabetes which was never a problem before synthroid and the weight gain.  My vote is for the Family Doctor who spends up to 30 minutes each visitas opposed to the Endo who zips me in & out and never seems to listen.

I have a great internal medicine doctor who believes in adding in a blend of complementary medicine. She is the main dr treating my thyroid, BUT I have a good endo who oversees my ultrasounds and hashi's.

I just recently found a great internal doctor:) I am in shock because today was the first day I woke up without my head in a bubble:) I am blessed and hoping that I will have many more days like this:)

question: Where do you find you are getting the best care for your thyroid problems? Where have you seen the most improvement of your symptoms? How comfortable are you with this doctor and feel he/she is really helping you?This question pops up so much - I figured I would run a poll and see where the chips fall.
title: What kind of doctor gives YOU the best treatment options?
